translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: How Upanishad became the recognised name of the philosophical treatises contained in the Veda is difficult to explain. Most European scholars are agreed in deriving

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: p. lxxx

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: upa-ni-shad from the root sad, to sit down, preceded by the two prepositions ni, down, and upa, near, so that it would express the idea of session, or assembly of pupils sitting down near their teacher to listen to his instruction. In the Trikâ n d a s esha, upanishad is explained by samîpasadana, sitting down near a person 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Such a word, however, would have been applicable, it would seem, to any other portion of the Veda as well as to the chapters called Upanishad, and it has never been explained how its meaning came thus to be restricted. It is still more strange that upanishad, in the sense of session or assembly, has never, so far as I am aware, been met with. Whenever the word occurs, it has the meaning of doctrine, secret doctrine, or is simply used as the title of the philosophic treatises which constitute the g ñânakâ n d a, the knowledge portion, as opposed to the karmakâ n d a, the work or ceremonial portion, of the Veda.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Native philosophers seem never to have thought of deriving upanishad from sad, to sit down. They derive it either from the root sad, in the sense of destruction, supposing these ancient treatises to have received their name because they were intended to destroy passion and ignorance by means of divine revelation 2 , or from the root sad, in the sense of approaching, because a knowledge of Brahman comes near to us by means of the Upanishads, or because we approach Brahman by their help. Another explanation proposed by S aṅkara in his commentary on the Taittirîya-upanishad II, 9, is that the highest bliss is contained in the Upanishad (para m s reyo 'syâ m nisha n n am).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: These explanations seem so wilfully perverse that it is difficult to understand the unanimity of native scholars. We ought to take into account, however, that very general tendency among half-educated people, to acquiesce in any etymology which accounts for the most prevalent meaning of a word. The Âra n yakas abound in

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: p. lxxxi

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: such etymologies, which probably were never intended as real etymologies, in our sense of the word, but simply as plays on words, helping to account somehow for their meaning. The Upanishads, no doubt, were meant to destroy ignorance and passion, and nothing seemed more natural therefore than that their etymological meaning should be that of destroyers 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The history and the genius of the Sanskrit language leave little doubt that upanishad meant originally session, particularly a session consisting of pupils, assembled at a respectful distance round their teacher.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: With upa alone, sad occurs as early as the hymns of the Rig-veda, in the sense of approaching respectfully 2 :--

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Rig-veda IX, 11, 6. Námasâ ít úpa sîdata, 'approach him with praise.' See also Rig-veda X, 73, II; I, 65, I.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: In the Kh ândogya-upanishad VI, 13, I, a teacher says to his pupil, atha mâ prâtar upasîdathâ h , 'come to me (for advice) to-morrow morning.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: In the same Upanishad VII, 8, I, a distinction is made between those who serve their teachers (pari k aritâ), and those who are admitted to their more intimate society (upasattâ, comm. samîpaga h , antaraṅga h , priya h ).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Again, in the Kh ândogya-upanishad VII, I, we read of a pupil approaching his teacher (upâsasâda or upasasâda), and of the teacher telling him to approach with what he knows, i.e. to tell him first what he has learnt already (yad vettha tena mopasîda 3 ).

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: In the Sûtras (Gobhilîya G ri hya-sûtra II, 10, 38) upasad is the recognised term for the position assumed by a pupil with his hands folded and his eyes looking up to the teacher who is to instruct him.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: It should be stated, however, that no passage has yet been met with in which upa-ni-sad is used in the sense of pupils approaching and listening to their teacher. In the

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: p. lxxxii

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: only passage in which upanishasâda occurs (Ait. Âr. II, 2, 1), it is used of Indra sitting down by the side of Vi s vâmitra, and it is curious to observe that both MSS. and commentaries give here upanishasasâda, an entirely irregular form.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The same is the case with two other roots which are used almost synonymously with sad, viz. âs and vi s . We find upa + âs used to express the position which the pupil occupies when listening to his teacher, e g . Pâ n . III, 4, 72, upâsito gurum bhavân, 'thou hast approached the Guru,' or upâsito gurur bhavatâ, 'the Guru has been approached by thee.' We find pari + upa + âs used with regard to relations assembled round the bed of a dying friend, Kh ând. Up. VI, 15; or of hungry children sitting round their mother, and likened to people performing the Agnihotra sacrifice ( Kh ând. Up. V, 24, 5). But I have never met with upa-ni-as in that sense.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: We likewise find upa-vis used in the sense of sitting down to a discussion ( Kh ând. Up. I, 8, 2), but I have never found upa + ni + vis as applied to a pupil listening to his teacher.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The two prepositions upa and ni occur, however, with pat, to fly, in the sense of flying down and settling near a person, Kh ând. Up. IV, 7, 2; IV, 8, 2. And the same prepositions joined to the verb s ri, impart to it the meaning of sitting down beneath a person, so as to show him respect: B ri h. Âr. I, 4, II. 'Although a king is exalted, he sits down at the end of the sacrifice below the Brahman,' brahmaivântata upani s rayati.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Sad, with upa and ni, occurs in upanishâdin only, and has there the meaning of subject, e g . Satap. Brâhm. IX, 4, 3, 3, kshatrâya tad vi s am adhastâd upanishâdinî m karoti, 'he thus makes the Vi s (citizen) below, subject to the Kshatriya.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Sometimes nishad is used by the side of upanishad, and so far as we can judge, without any difference of meaning 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: All we can say therefore, for the present, is that upanishad,

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: p. lxxxiii

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: besides being the recognised title of certain philosophical treatises, occurs also in the sense of doctrine and of secret doctrine, and that it seems to have assumed this meaning from having been used originally in the sense of session or assembly in which one or more pupils receive instruction from a teacher.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Thus we find the word upanishad used in the Upanishads themselves in the following meanings:

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1. Secret or esoteric explanation, whether true or false.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Knowledge derived from such explanation.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. Special rules or observances incumbent on those who have received such knowledge.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. Title of the books containing such knowledge.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: I. Ait. Âr. III, 1, 6, 3. 'For this Upanishad, i.e. in order to obtain the information about the true meaning of Sa m hitâ, Târukshya served as a cowherd for a whole year.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Taitt. Up. 1, 3. 'We shall now explain the Upanishad of the Sa m hitâ.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Ait. Âr. III, 2, 5, 1. 'Next follows this Upanishad of the whole speech. True, all these are Upanishads of the whole speech, but this they declare especially.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Talav. Up. IV, 7. 'As you have asked me to tell you the Upanishad, the Upanishad has now been told you. We have told you the Brâhmî Upanishad,' i.e. the true meaning of Brahman.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: In the Kh ând. Up. III, II, 3, after the meaning of Brahman has been explained, the text says: 'To him who thus knows this Brahma upanishad (the secret doctrine of Brahman) the sun does not rise and does not set.' In the next paragraph brahma itself is used, meaning either Brahman as the object taught in the Upanishad, or, by a slight change of meaning, the Upanishad itself.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Kh ând. Up. I, 13, 4. 'Speech yields its milk to him who knows this Upanishad (secret doctrine) of the Sâmans in this wise.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Kh ând. Up. VIII, 8, 4. When Indra and Virokana had both misunderstood the teaching of Pragâpati, he says: 'They both go away without having perceived and without having known the Self, and whoever of these two, whether

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: p. lxxxiv

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Devas or Asuras, will follow this doctrine (upanishad), will perish.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: II. In the Kh ând. Up. I, i, after the deeper meaning of the Udgîtha or Om has been described, the advantage of knowing that deeper meaning is put forward, and it is said that the sacrifice which a man performs with knowledge, with faith, and with the Upanishad, i.e. with an understanding of its deeper meaning, is more powerful.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: III. In the Taittirîya-upanishad, at the end of the second chapter, called the Brahmânandavallî, and again at the end of the tenth chapter, the text itself says: Ity upanishad, this is the Upanishad, the true doctrine.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: IV. In the Kaushîtaki-upanishad II, I; 2, we read: 'Let him not beg, this is the Upanishad for him who knows this.' Here upanishad stands for vrata or rahasya-vrata, rule.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: lxxx:1 Pânini I, 4, 79, has upanishatk ri tya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: lxxx:2 M. M., History of Ancient Sanskrit Literature, p. 318; Colebrooke, Essays, I, 92; Regnaud, Matériaux, p. 7.
